results.name: A triangle formed like Pascal's triangle, but with (-1)^(n+1) on the borders instead of 1.
comment: This sequence is almost the same as A026637.
T(n,k) = A026637(n-2,k-1) for n > 3, 1 < k < n-1. - _Reinhard Zumkeller_, Aug 08 2013
link: T. D. Noe, Rows n = 0..50 of triangle, flattened
mathematica: t = {}; Do[r = {}; Do[If[k == 0 || k == n, m = (-1)^(n+1), m = t[[n, k]] + t[[n, k + 1]]]; r = AppendTo[r, m], {k, 0, n}]; AppendTo[t, r], {n, 0, 10}]; t = Flatten[t]
xref: Cf. A007318 (Pascal's triangle), A026637 (many terms in common).
Cf. A051601 (n on the borders), A137688 (2^n on borders).
Cf. A227074 (4^n edges), A227075 (3^n edges), A227076 (5^n edges).
